questions.question_text:
A security engineer is attempting to increase the randomness of numbers used in key generation in a system. The goal of the effort is to strengthen the keys against predictive analysis attacks.
Which of the following is the BEST solution?

choices.B: Loop multiple pseudo-random number generators in a series to produce larger numbers.
choices.C: Increase key length by two orders of magnitude to detect brute forcing.
choices.A: Use an entropy-as-a-service vendor to leverage larger entropy pools.
choices.D: Shift key generation algorithms to ECC algorithms.

comments.content: ECC doesn't have anything to do with number randomness, it has to do with elliptical numbers that are very hard to factor or guess. For number randomness, you want an entropy provider (lest you have to sit at a disk for hours and wiggle a mouse to get random coordinate points).

questions.question_text:
A security engineer is attempting to convey the importance of including job rotation in a company's standard security policies. Which of the following would be the
BEST justification?

discussion.content: B is probably the answer BUT job rotation doesn't force anyone to attempt collusion.

comments.content:
Agree. BTW: on an exam about security, I tend to lean towards answers that security concerns, as opposed to answers that relate towards general efficiency. 
This question specifically states: "importance of including job rotation in a company's standard *security* policies"

discussion.content:
B
I think that A addresses the importance of cross-training and COOP plans, but doesn't necessarily hit on the importance of job rotation, which specifically reduces malicious activity by keeping people from obfuscating what they're doing. I think the answer is B.
I think that B should be the correct answer.

comments.content: A, B, and C, are all good reasons for job rotation. But 'B' is more about information security. Since the exam is about information security, B might not be a bad choice.

choices.D: It eliminates the need to share administrative account passwords because employees gain administrative rights as they rotate into a new job area.
choices.B: Forcing different people to perform the same job minimizes the amount of time malicious actions go undetected by forcing malicious actors to attempt collusion between two or more people.
choices.C: Administrators and engineers who perform multiple job functions throughout the day benefit from being cross-trained in new job areas.
choices.A: Making employees rotate through jobs ensures succession plans can be implemented and prevents single points of failure.

questions.question_text:
A company is transitioning to a new VDI environment, and a system engineer is responsible for developing a sustainable security strategy for the VDIs.
Which of the following is the MOST appropriate order of steps to be taken?

choices.C: Firmware update, OS patching, HIDS, antivirus, monitoring agent, baseline
choices.D: Baseline, antivirus, OS patching, monitoring agent, HIDS, firmware update
choices.A: Firmware update, OS patching, HIDS, antivirus, baseline, monitoring agent
choices.B: OS patching, baseline, HIDS, antivirus, monitoring agent, firmware update

discussion.content:
A. Firmware update, OS patching, HIDS, antivirus, baseline, monitoring agent

You would get a baseline, then set up your monitoring agent to alert of anything that seems suspicious against our baseline.

comments.content:
Wouldn't the monitoring agent be gathering the data for the baseline? If so, then the monitoring agent must come before the baseline.
I think it should be C

You make a very good point. I have been researching how to setup a security baseline. From what I have found: you may, or may not, use a monitoring agent to create a baseline. 
I think the term "baseline" can be used to mean a standard hardening process. Or it can be used to mean normal network activity.

discussion.content:
Any chance it could be: C. Firmware update, OS patching, HIDS, antivirus, monitoring agent, baseline ?
Don't get a baseline until everything else is setup. Of course, that means you might have to go back and adjust your monitoring agent.

Which of the following types of information could be drawn from such participation?

comments.content: I agree. That was my first answer when reading the question

Which of the following types of information could be drawn from such participation?

Going beyond IP addresses, hashes, and other core threat identifiers, threat intelligence provides critical context around a threat activity, including indicators of compromise (IoC), indicators of attack (IoA), the tactics employed, and, potentially, the motivation and identity of the adversary.

That makes "Exploit frameworks" the correct answer.

I believe it is threat intelligence.

“Threat intelligence is the investigation and collection of emerging threats and emerging threat sources”
“An exercise in situational awareness that helps organizations understand how the may be susceptible to a multitude of the latest attacks”

Threat modeling = “What will the attacker try to attack, how will he likely do it”
Threat Intelligence = “What are the attacks, and who are the attackers”

So that leaves Modeling or Intelligence. It asks for specific emerging attack information. Therefore Threat intelligence.

questions.question_text:
The Chief Information Officer (CIO) has been asked to develop a security dashboard with the relevant metrics. The board of directors will use the dashboard to monitor and track the overall security posture of the organization. The CIO produces a basic report containing both KPI and KRI data in two separate sections for the board to review.
Which of the following BEST meets the needs of the board?

discussion.content:
Maybe B or C?
One metric I feel fairly certain is a KRI is "Threat landscape rating." No way that could be a performance rating. This would narrow it down to B or C. Of those two choices, I would lean towards C.

Key Risk Indicators (KRI) are metrics that predict potential risks. Key Performance Indicators (KPI) measure progress toward an intended result. 
Problem is, since you are always working towards eliminating as much risk as you practically can, the same item might seem like both a KPI and KRI. For example: a company wants "compliance with regulations" to be 100%. So if compliance is 50%, that tells the company their *performance* in that regard. Or another way to look at it: the is at 50% *risk* of being out of compliance. The better your "EDR coverage across the fleet" the lower your *risk* - which means that "EDR coverage across the fleet" is a measurement of *performance* towards lowering that risk.

comments.content: I think "Compliance with regulations" has to come first. I also think that is a risk indicator, nor a performance indicator. Tough call, but I think I will stick with A.

Key Performance Indicators (KPI) measure progress toward an intended result. So I can see how "Compliance with regulations" is a KPI. But if that is a KPI, then why isn't "EDR coverage across the fleet" also a KPI, and not a KRI?
I think Compliance with regulations is a KPI, KPI looks backward, KRI looks forward. Compliance is what we did, not what we predict. I think C here.
No way "threat landscape rating" could be a KPI.

discussion.content: The only issue i see with A as the answer is time to patch critical issues. KPI is a quantifiable metric. That should have been a KPI. I leaning towards C as the answer.
